title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate real GDP per capita for Mavington for Year 2 as $40, does not calculate real GDP per capita for Harrison for Year 2 as $25, and/or does not show the work.

( Nominal GDP GDP Deflator ×100 )÷Population=( $720 120 ×100 )÷15=$40 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6EFA@

( Nominal GDP GDP Deflator ×100 )÷Population=( $525 105 ×100 )÷20=$25 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6EFF@

The response calculates real GDP per capita for Mavington for Year 2 as $40, calculates real GDP per capita for Harrison for Year 2 as $25, and shows the work.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that Mavington has the higher money supply in Year 2 and/or does not explain that using the quantity theory of money ( MV=PY MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGnbGaaeOvaiaab2dacaqGqbGaaeywaaaa@3D14@ ), since the two nations have the same velocity of money and Mavington has a higher nominal GDP in Year 2, Mavington has the higher money supply.

The response states that Mavington has the higher money supply in Year 2 and explains that using the quantity theory of money ( MV=PY MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGnbGaaeOvaiaab2dacaqGqbGaaeywaaaa@3D14@ ), since the two nations have the same velocity of money and Mavington has a higher nominal GDP in Year 2, Mavington has the higher money supply.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the inflation rate in Mavington in Year 2 as 20%, does not calculate the inflation rate in Harrison in Year 2 as 5%, and/or does not show the work.

Year 2 GDP Deflator−Year 1 GDP Deflator Year 1 GDP Deflator ×100= 120−100 100 ×100=20% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@8166@

Year 2 GDP Deflator−Year 1 GDP Deflator Year 1 GDP Deflator ×100= 105−100 100 ×100=5% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@80B2@

The response calculates the inflation rate in Mavington in Year 2 as 20%, calculates the inflation rate in Harrison in Year 2 as 5%, and shows the work.

Year 2 GDP Deflator−Year 1 GDP Deflator Year 1 GDP Deflator ×100= 120−100 100 ×100=20% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@8166@

Year 2 GDP Deflator−Year 1 GDP Deflator Year 1 GDP Deflator ×100= 105−100 100 ×100=5% MathType@MTEF@5@5@@80B2@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that Harrison experienced the higher real interest rate and/or does not explain that Harrison had lower inflation and the real interest rate is equal to the nominal interest rate minus the inflation rate.

The response states that Harrison experienced the higher real interest rate and explains that Harrison had lower inflation and the real interest rate is equal to the nominal interest rate minus the inflation rate.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that real GDP in Harrison will increase and/or does not explain that actual inflation is less than expected inflation, which means that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right (or the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left) until expected inflation adjusts to actual inflation.

The response states that real GDP in Harrison will increase and explains that actual inflation is less than expected inflation, which means that the short-run aggregate supply curve will shift to the right (or the short-run Phillips curve will shift to the left) until expected inflation adjusts to actual inflation.
